Your insight raises some crucial points in this debate. The long-term sustainability and affordability of Obamacare due to high out of pocket costs are indeed noteworthy concerns. However, the question at hand – "Is Obamacare working?" – is more complex than this single aspect would imply.

Firstly, it's important to note that while high deductibles and co-pays can lead to financial strains, they are not unique to Obamacare. They are common features of many health insurance systems, serving as a mechanism to prevent over-utilization of healthcare services.

Secondly, according to studies by the National Center for Health Statistics, the uninsured rate dropped from 16% in 2010 when ACA was signed into law, to 8.8% in 2017. That means more than 20 million people gained coverage during these years because of Obamacare. This suggests that, at least from a coverage perspective, Obamacare has achieved a significant part of its intended purpose.

Lastly, evaluating whether a complex piece of legislation, like Obamacare, is "working" or not, requires analyzing several other factors beyond cost-related issues. These would include, for example, if the legislation has indeed incentivized preventive care, or reduced the burden on emergency departments.

So, while I agree with you that high out-of-pocket costs can be a burden for some and a potential flaw in the system, I still believe it may be too soon and too simplistic to deduce from this one standpoint that Obamacare is not working. It's vital that we continue to see these issues in a broader context and work toward refining the system, rather than declaring it unsuccessful based on a single metric.
